pr_title: Publish topic messages to redis in a separate thread

timeline.message:
- publish topic messages to redis service in a separate thread
- integration tests

- publish topic messages to redis service in a separate thread
- integration tests

Signed-off-by: Xin Li <xin.li@swirlds.com>

- publish topic messages to redis service in a separate thread

timeline.body: leave `TASK_QUEUE_SIZE` as a static non-configurable field due to spring validation penalty on `redisProperties.isEnabled()` which is checked in every `onSave()` invocation.

timeline.body:
nit: please add a bit more content to this to highlight the intricacies of the flux here. 
If my understanding is correct you're generating topicmessage and adding to the sink, whiles supporting subscription on a single thread with messages in the pipeline converted and published. 

This is something I'm pushing for with all our reactive streams to ensure the intent is clear and make it easier to understand and manage future changes/improvements.

timeline.body: I'm still learning the ins and outs of Flux, if there were a period where no messages were coming in would this cause the `complete()` to close the Flux?  And then what would happen if messages were then to come in later, would it generate a new Flux?  This code looks good, just trying to make sure I understand.

timeline.author: ijungmann

timeline.bodyHTML:
When I said we should consider Flux I meant replace things entirely with it. We shouldn't mix and match non-blocking Flux with blocking queues and regular array lists. We should either use all flux or all BlockingQueue with a regular thread. For latter can just have a method like below:

@Async
@EventListener
public void onStartup(ApplicationReadyEvent event) {
  while (true) {
    publish(topicMessagesQueue.take());
  }
}

For Flux only approach, can actually remove queue and list and just create a flux on startup like below (exact processor, overflow strategy and values would need to be investigated):

void init() {
  DirectProcessor<TopicMessage> directProcessor = DirectProcessor.create();
  topicMessageSink = directProcessor.sink();
  directProcessor.filter(last timestamp)
    .bufferTimeout(1000, Duration.ofSeconds(1))
    .subscribeOn(Schedulers.single())
    .subscribe(this::publish);
}

public void onTopicMessage(TopicMessage topicMessage) {
  topicMessageSink.next(topicMessage);
}

Flux only approach would have the added benefit of allowing us to remove batch onSave() and make the class stateless.
timeline.author: steven-sheehy

replies.bodyText:
Looks like there isn't a way to achieve the following at the same time:

use Flux only approach
run the redis publish in a different thread
block the parser thread when downstream redis publish is blocked / slow
not rely on non-flux mechanism for example BlockingQueue

The DirectProcessor and subscribeOn approach does not work as expected, it turns out to be the whole flux pipeline runs in the same thread sink.next/error/complete is called.
UnicastProcessor may honor subscribeOn, and when created with a BlockingQueue, we can achieve the first 3 goals but not the last. Same as DirectProcessor, the queue for UnicastProcessor is used as the buffer internally between processor and downstream subscribers.
So sounds like using @Async with BlockingQueue is the way to go.
replies.author: xin-hedera

replies.bodyText: @Async and @EventListener cause BeanNotOfRequiredTypeException, so instead, use Executor to run the publish task.
replies.author: xin-hedera

replies.bodyText:
block the parser thread when downstream redis publish is blocked / slow

Technically the requirement is don't increase memory unbounded. Blocking is just one approach to do that. Other is to throw an error when queue maxed (e.g. backpressure) and retry in the next poll. But am fine with Async if that accomplishes our goals.
replies.author: steven-sheehy

timeline.body: Should be made volatile or AtomicLong. Sonar seems to complain about volatile even when used properly, so maybe AtomicLong.
